answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Kristi,
Unfortunately I was unable to find any specific examples of how a local government has put such a plan into place. However, I found some resources that will hopefully be helpful in creating alternatives with electric companies and solar energy.
To begin, the Department of Energy created a document called “Solar Powering Your Community: A Guide for Local Governments.” This document was designed to help local governments and stakeholders in building sustainable local solar markets. Section 2.3 details what is called “Feed-In Tariffs,” which requires energy suppliers to buy electricity produced from renewable resources at a fixed price, usually over a period of 15-20 years. In section 4.1, the report details how to use interconnection standards. Along with this description are best practices and additional informational resources:
http://bit.ly/jmvkOC
Additionally, there is the Database of State Incentives for Renewables + Energy (DSIRE). This site gives information about state, local, utility, and federal incentives and policies that promote sustainable practices such as solar energy. 
http://www.dsireusa.org/
I hope these at least begin to help with your research!
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-932-3699
adodge@icma.org
